page.title: 01Valleys and Hills of Luppitt
page.content: Central Luppitt, in an area of outstanding natural beauty, has many small dairy and stock rearing farms. The village, dominated by St Marys' Church, has close links with the Norman Conquest. The manor originally owned by the Flemmings and then the Mohuns is bordered by the river Otter. Sir George Carew (whose family later owned the manor) lived here and as vice admiral of the Mary Rose was drowned in 1545 when the ill fated ship capsized near Portsmouth. In 1982 this ship was raised and is undergoing restoration. The surrounding countryside comprises of a laqrge area of common land, much of which was brought into cultivation during World War II, has been improved and is now collectively farmed.
